description.narrative: Fundamental principles and practices for good governance will be built for key national institutions for effective management of public resources, access to justice and information.

participating-org.narrative: FOOD AND AGRICULTURE ORGANIZATION OF THE UNITED NATIONS

description.narrative: 1. % of legal advisors in line ministries 2. # of state party reports compiled and submitted timely 3. # of key government officials trained in Public Finance Management 4. # of Anti Corruption Commission (ACC) and Swaziland Revenue Authority (SRA) staff trained in accountability and transparency issues, including Leadership Code of Conduct. 5. Functional electronic file system for court cases 6. # of Judiciary staff, police and law society members trained in addressing challenges in accessing justice 7.Legal aid framework developed 8.Number of cases reviewed by the Commission on Human Rights and Public Administration (CHRPA) 9.# of civic education interventions on the importance of equal participation and representation of all parts of society 10.# of people from under-represented groups trained in leadership and election campaigning 11. # of candidates from underrepresented groups that stand for national elections

comment.narrative: 1. 2008: Three (3) bills gazetted and Four (4) pieces of legislation have been reviewed. 2. Limited legal capacity in line ministries. 3. 2010: CEDAW and Second National Communications drafts in place. 4. 2010: 120 senior government officials have received training in Accountability and Integrity. 5. Aid Coordination Policy of 2000 in place. Excel-based data capture system for External Aid Management System exists but not operational. 6. 2010: No public servants received training in Public Financial Management systems or processes. 7. In 2010: no advocacy activities conducted on anti-corruption, transparency and accountability.

1. Provide Technical support for the development of a national E-procurement strategy. 2. Provide technical assistance from RSC for the development of a procurement agenda and capacity building 3. Develop and monitor regional development plans for effective decentralization of services 4. Establish a pay a bribe reporting website as means for mitigating corruption within public service delivery 5. Provide support for the branding of e-governance initiative 6. Develop public sector HIV Mainstreaming guidelines 7. Provide Technical Assistance for undertaking a national corruption perception survey 8. Provide technical and normative support for the development of tools and analysis of the public sector customer satisfaction survey 9. Support the preparation of the Status report on Human rights in Swaziland (Human Rights Baseline in Swaziland) 10. Provide technical support for conducting a sexual harassment study within public and private sector 11. Support consultations for the development of a Swaziland Governance Index 12. Provide Technical Support for the development of a Gender Equality Index 13. Support CANGO establishment of Key populations consortium 14. Provide technical support for the development of Key populations strategic plan 15. Support Parliament with the development of an interactive website 16. Strengthen capacity of Parliamentarians on the implementation of of the 2016 Standing Orders 17. Develop guidelines for Domestication of International Conventions 18. Support the roll out of the community score card for monitoring service delivery 19. Strengthen resource mobilization for the establishment of an e- Parliament; citizens participation in the local authority; access to justice

1-2. Public Procurement Capacity Assessment Report; Capacity e-Procurement Readiness Assessment Report and Capacity Building Plan for Government and Local Authorities has been completed and adopted by the SPPRA Board. The procurement assessment adopted the UN online tools SUPREM designed for a systematic assessment of risks involved in the procurement of goods, services and works in the public and local authority sector. This covered organisational systems and procedures, procurement transactions and change management strategies for the transformation of the Government procurement systems. A systematic reform agenda was also prepared for SPPRA. Public Sector Officials and Local Authority CEOs and Board Members were trained on the SUPREM tools and assessed for e-procurement readiness. Further the Public Procurement Regulations to operationalize the Public Procurement Law were reviewed and recommendations ensuring alignment with international standards was undertaken. The revised regulations have been tabled at cabinet for approval (IRRF 2.2.2)
3.The Ministry of Ministry of Tinkhundla Administration and Development and Ministry of Housing and Urban Development Parliamentary Portfolio Committees were re-oriented on the Tinkhundla Administration Bill which seeks to operationalize the Decentralization Policy and increase citizen’s participation in development. Envisaged was on adoption of the Bill by Parliament development plans were to be developed in piloted Constituencies in line with the structures established by the Bill. The Bill is still in Parliament awaiting approval.
1. A system for reporting bribery at public service receiving points has been developed. This is a web based system which should be accessible through mobile. Citizens being extorted to pay a bribe for a public service can report through this system. This will also help with the collection of data and generating annual reports on the extent of bribery in Swaziland. The system is being finalized and will be piloted in January 2017 for 3 months before being rolled out. Civil Society Organisations will be encouraged to use data for advocacy purposes.
2. The E-Government communication strategy was developed and approved by Cabinet in 2016. The strategy recommends a participatory approach towards the branding of e-government initiatives. Competitions for citizens to submit creative Logos for branding eGovernment has been completed. The top three logos have been presented to the Prime Minister and Cabinet for the final selection. Documentation of e-government initiatives since the launch of the strategy in 2013 is also underway to be completed before the year end.
3. The HIV mainstreaming Guidelines have been completed. The guidelines provide indicators and guidance for the integration of HIV in core Ministerial mandates for sustainability of the national response. The mainstreaming of HIV into national government programmes and plans will be led by the Ministry of Economic Planning and Development.
4. The National Corruption Perception Survey is currently underway, consultation with citizens is ongoing and the study will be completed in 2017. A similar study was undertaken in 2010 which indicated that corruption was perceived to be high in the public sector. Findings from this survey will also serve as baseline for the Swaziland Development Index.
5. The tools for conducting the public service customer satisfaction survey were developed and data was collected from over 3500 citizens from the 55 Constituencies. The report is presently being finalized by the Ministry of Tinkhundla Administration and Development and will be presented to stakeholder in the first quarter of 2017 (IRRF 3.2.1).
6. Phase one of the Status Report on Human Rights consisting of desk review of legal frameworks, policy documents, focus group and key informants’ consultation with various stakeholders (duty bearers and rights holders) and development of quantitative data collection tools for the second phase has been completed. The first draft report presented to the CHRPA for review. Validation of the first draft status report; review of the tools and data collection for quantitative data will be undertaken in the first quarter of 2017 (Phase 2) (IRRF 2.1.1b; 2.3.1)
7. Sexual Harassment Study first draft report has been submitted and comments being incorporated into the document. The study should be completed by the end of 2016 and validated in 2017. This will be followed by the development of a comprehensive programme aimed at the reduction of sexual harassment at workplace (IRRF 4.2.1).
8. Advocacy needs to be sustained with the Government to clearly articulate its priority of focus for strengthening the governance system. The list of indicators has been prepared and further discussions to be held with the Government Prime Minister’s Office. SDG 16 provides an opportunity for further engagement.
9. Partnership was established with UNECA for the establishment of the Swaziland Gender Index. The study has been completed and yet to be launched. The UNECA index focused on very specific variables. Its encouraged that all the gender equality variables are included in this final report so it’s inclusive of all variables (IRRF 3.4.2).
13-14. A Key Populations Consortium has been established, constituted of five NGO representing the LGBT community. The Consortium held its first Advocacy meeting with Members of Parliament where matters facing LGBT community were discussed. Following the finalization of the LEA report in 2015 an action plan for the implementation of the recommendations has been developed (IRRF 2.6.1).
15. The Parliament Service Board responsible for the implementation of the Parliament Strategic Plan has been established and Corporate Governance training was provided to the members of PSB. The training focused on the role a PSB and its functions as outlined in the Constitution. Parliament has also been supported with the development of an interactive website. The website should provide information on parliament operations, proceedings, and also run live debates for citizens to follow on line (2.1.1)
16. Standing Orders could not be finalized, draft standing orders still awaiting adoption by the House (IRRF 2.1.1).
17 An Inter-Ministerial Committee constituting of Legal Advisors and Directors has been established. Terms of references for the Committee presented to Cabinet for adoption. The Inter Ministerial Committee will be responsible for the coordination of the drafting of Treaty State Reports. They will also be responsible for monitoring of the implementation of recommendations from the various treaty Committees including the UPR. The Ministry of Justice and Constitutional Affairs was also supported with the drafting of the 2016 UPR report, further support will be provided towards the development of an action plan for the recommendation. The MOJCA has also been supported in strengthening its coordination mechanisms and the midterm review of its strategic plan ending 2017.
18. Community score card could not be facilitated with CANGO. Strategies for strengthening the role of civil society organisations in the designing of effective systems for monitoring public services and sustainable development goals need to be established within CSO.
19. Resource mobilization through a development partner’s roundtable for the implementation of the Parliament Strategy and for e-Parliament could not be facilitated. Lack of leadership at Parliament Secretariat level makes it a challenge to resource mobilize. There is need for more ownership for initiatives targeting parliament at a much higher level.
20. A comprehensive analysis of the Judicature has been completed. The Assessment focused on organisational development, systems and procedures of the all courts (Supreme Court, High Court, Magistrate courts, industrial court and Masters Office and Administration of Estates and the Swazi law Courts). Recommendations from the assessment informed the development of the Judicature Strategic Plan 2017 -2021. The Judicature Strategic Plan and assessment report will be validated in 2017.
Partnership was also established with the South African Litigation Center to facilitate a Judgment Writing Seminar for the Judges, attended by 37 Judges (15 Judges of the High Court and 22 Magistrates). The workshop was held over 2 days and introduced Justices into different techniques of preparing judgments.
Further partnership was established with LexisNexis a South African company that provides on line legal research solutions. A thirty-day trial of the system was afforded to 40 Judges from the Supreme Court, Magistrates and Industrial Court. The LexisNexis is a platform that allows Judges to conduct research and linked to case law. The utilization of the LexisNexis research platform is yet to be reviewed in terms of its effectiveness.
21. HIV and Wellness Policy for the Public Sector and the PHSHACC HIV Wellness Strategic Plan have been completed. Final validation has been done and the final inputs are being incorporated into the document.

Support the roll out of the community score card for monitoring service delivery 19. 1. Parliament, Judiciary and Ministry of Justice and Constitutional Affairs (MOJCA) capacities for law reform strengthened: Number of Members of Parliament trained on law reform and legislation development cycle advocate for enactment of legislation; Inventory for legislation to be aligned to the Constitution and International Conventions (through IMC) developed. 2. Ministry of Justice and Constitutional Affairs (MOJCA), and Parliament’s Capacity on Treaty Body Reporting strengthened: Guidelines for the mainstreaming and domestication of international conventions; Number of Portfolio Chairpersons trained on Treaty Body reporting. 3. Human Rights capacities and integration into national development enhanced: Human Rights Baseline Report disseminated; Number of Judiciary, Security Forces (Correctional Services & Police) on Human Rights Conventions; Human Rights day; Anti-Corruption Day; Disability Day commemorated. 4. Increased advocacy and interaction of citizens with access to justice and human right machinery: Ministry of Justice and Constitutional Affairs (MOJCA), Anti-Corruption Commission (ACC), Commission for Human Rights and Public Administration (CHRPA), Swaziland Public Procurement Regulatory Authority (SPPRA) Coordination Framework; Advocacy and Communication Strategy for access to justice; MOJCA Strategic Plan; Judicial Assessment and Strategic Plan. 5. National Performance Measurement Systems established at national and local levels: Number of codes of conduct for key public institutions developed. 6. National capacities for public procurement strengthened: Community of Practice for Procurement Officers; Standard of Practice for public procurement; On-line training platform. 7. Sector-specific corruption risk, including in public procurement improved: Corruption Perception Survey Report; ‘Pay a bribe’ on-line reporting platform operationalized. 8. Key populations advocacy strategies strengthened for increased access to preventive service; Legal Environment Assessment Report Disseminated (LEA); LEA Key Populations Action Plan, and; Non- Discrimination guidelines for policy interventions and legal reform. 9. Citizens’ Voice and Participation in National and local elections strengthened: Number of advocacy events/campaigns/civic education on women representation. 10. Public and private sectors more aware on impact of Sexual Harassment: Sexual Harassment Assessment Report disseminated; On-line reporting on Sexual Harassment operationalized. 11. National capacities for SDG-based planning: SDG Analysis Report and Prioritization of SDGs Report; Enhanced advocacy and communication on SDGs.

1. The Ministry of Justice and Constitutional Affairs and Parliament’s capacity for Treaty Body Reporting was strengthened. Collaboration with OHCHR led to training of the inter-ministerial team resulting in the production of the Children Rights Convention (CRC) Report which has been tabled to the Cabinet for approval. 2. While the rule of law capacities were enabled for strategic undertaking through the development of the Judicature Strategy and Action Plan 2017-2021. The plan called for the approval of the 2016 Legal Aid Policy and Legal Aid Bill enactment as well as piloting of the case management at the High Court. 3. Human Rights capacities and integration into national development was enhanced leading to the development of the Human Rights Baseline Report. The Report adoption resulted in training of 90 Security Forces from the Correctional Services and Royal Swaziland Police Services on Human Rights. Advocacy for upholding and protection of human rights was also supported through the commemoration of the Human Rights Day. The commemoration of the Anti-Corruption Day facilitated the dissemination of the UNDP-supported second Corruption Perception Survey Report following one conducted in 2010. The Report revealed high corruption perception levels at 93%, with the public sector leading (78%) on malpractice. On the other hand, advocacy for inclusive economy growth for people living with disabilities was encouraged during the Disability Day commemoration 4. UNDP supported the Deputy Prime Minister’s Office, Department of Gender and Family Issues (DPMO-DGFI) with the development of the Swaziland Gender Development Index, leading to the establishment of the gender equality status using the UNECA tool along the political, social and economic sectors. Significant gaps were noted in the political sector given retrogression in representation of women in parliament from 22% in 2013 to 15% in 2018. The Index status also revealed that men have a stronghold in the economy sector with better job opportunities than women, while the male-child’s retention in secondary schools was recorded worse-off as well as demand for basic health care services, including for HIV, which lags for men. 5. The e-Government Strategy for the Government of Swaziland was launched, promoting service delivery and led to various sectors adopting innovative interventions such as development of the interactive Parliament website for Bill-tracking. The Ministry of Tinkhundla Administration and Development (MTAD) benchmarked the public service delivery through the production of the Public Service Customer Satisfaction Study Report. Various public services were mapped and the community satisfaction status for five (5) sectors: agriculture, health, public works, education and water, was established. 6. The Sexual Harassment Assessment Report was finalised together with the development of Technical Paper for dissemination in 2018 first quarter to the Private Sector recommend doing on the development of the on-line reporting on Sexual Harassment which was however not operationalized. 7. National capacities for SDG-based planning: SDG Analysis Report and Prioritization of SDGs Report; Enhanced advocacy and communication on SDGs were facilitated under Project ID 00077632. 8. The CO prioritized support for the implementation of several activities namely: the operationalization of the 2016 Parliament Strategy and Action Plan; development of the Inventory of Laws for alignment to the 2005 National Constitution; development of the Leadership Code of Conduct and National Performance Measurement System for the public sector; LEA Key Populations Report dissemination; and prevention of corruption in the national procurement procedures through the development of Standard of Practice guidelines, establishment of a training platform and formation of a Community of Practice for Procurement Officers. These activities could not be supported due to financial constraints.

1. Parliament, Judiciary and Ministry of Justice and Constitutional Affairs (MOJCA) capacities for law reform strengthened: Inventory for legislation to be aligned to the Constitution and International Conventions (through IMC) developed. Advocate and support (in-house) drafting of selected Bills (4): Marriages and Matrimonial Property Bill; Administration of Estates Bill; Intestate Succession Bill. 2. Ministry of Justice and Constitutional Affairs (MOJCA), and Parliament’s Capacity on Treaty Body Reporting strengthened: CEDAW and CRC reports drafted and submitted; ICESCR drafted. 3. Human Rights capacities and integration into national development enhanced: Human Rights Baseline Report disseminated; National Human Rights Plan aligned to SDGs 16 developed. 4. National Performance Measurement Systems established at national and local levels: Number of codes of conduct for key public institutions developed. 5. National capacities for public procurement strengthened: Community of Practice for Procurement Officers; Standard of Practice for public procurement; On-line training platform. 6. Sector-specific corruption risk, including in public procurement improved: Corruption Perception Survey Report; Anti Corruption Policy Drafted and finalized. 7. Citizens’ Voice and Participation in National and local elections strengthened: Number of advocacy events/campaigns/civic education on women representation. 8. Public and private sectors more aware on impact of Sexual Harassment: Sexual Harassment Assessment Report disseminated; On-line reporting on Sexual Harassment operationalized. 9. National capacities for SDG-based planning: SDG Analysis Report and Prioritization of SDGs Report; Enhanced advocacy and communication on SDGs.

1. UNDP supported MOJCA with the alignment of 1 of the 4 family related laws; the Marriages Act. The review involved stakeholders engagement including the traditional authorities. The Act now awaits to be submitted to parliament for endorsement. Due to limited resources, the progress on the alignment of the identified laws has been slow. The review and alignment of the Estates Act has also been started with an internal drafting process. The review of the 2010 National Gender Policy is underway for completion in the second quarter of 2019. The Inception Report for the project has been produced. 2. The International and Regional Treaty Reporting was enabled for the CEDAW Third Report, Maputo declaration and SADC Protocol drafts. UNDP together with UNICEF supported the Deputy Prime Ministers office with the development and finalisation of the The National Disability and Implementation Plan which has been launched. This has led to the fast-tracking on the treaty reporting on Disability. Through Joint work with OHCHR institutional design and training of human capacity for 30 Officers from across Government Ministries international treaty body reporting focusing in particular on the Disability Report has been facilitated. Engagement of national Stakeholders on UPR and ICCPR recommendations has been facilitated. The outcome of this facilitation is the monitoring plan for implementation of the recommendations. 3. Not achieved. 4. Workshop was facilitated for heads f departments of 7 key service Ministries (Agriculture Health, education, Home Affairs, Natural Resources and Public Works) involved in Public Service delivery to disseminate the results of the Public service perception study and develop an action plan on how to roll out recommendations and to develop public Service score cards. 5. Due to resource constraints this was not achieved. 6. The Drafting of the Anti Corruption Policy was initiated, however due to Resources Constraints could not be finalised. 7. Support was extended to the gender Unit and family unit for the media campaign for the vote for women campaign in collaboration with UNFPA. 8. Dissemination of the Sexual Harassment Assessment Report facilitated involving stakeholders from private sector. The outcome from this dissemination study is the development of an action plan.

1. Parliament, Judiciary and Ministry of Justice and Constitutional Affairs (MOJCA) capacities for law reform strengthened: Inventory for legislation to be aligned to the Constitution and International Conventions (through IMC) developed. Advocate and support (in-house) drafting of selected Bills (4): Marriages and Matrimonial Property Bill; Administration of Estates Bill; Intestate Succession Bill. 2. Ministry of Justice and Constitutional Affairs (MOJCA), and Parliament’s Capacity on Treaty Body Reporting strengthened: CEDAW and CRC reports drafted and submitted; ICESCR drafted. 3. Human Rights capacities and integration into national development enhanced: Human Rights Baseline Report disseminated; National Human Rights Plan aligned to SDGs 16 developed. 4. National Performance Measurement Systems established at national and local levels: Number of codes of conduct for key public institutions developed. 5. National capacities for public procurement strengthened: Community of Practice for Procurement Officers; Standard of Practice for public procurement; On-line training platform. 6. Sector-specific corruption risk, including in public procurement improved: Corruption Perception Survey Report; Anti Corruption Policy Drafted and finalized. 7. Citizens’ Voice and Participation in National and local elections strengthened: Number of advocacy events/campaigns/civic education on women representation. 8. Public and private sectors more aware on impact of Sexual Harassment: Sexual Harassment Assessment Report disseminated; On-line reporting on Sexual Harassment operationalized. 9. National capacities for SDG-based planning: SDG Analysis Report and Prioritization of SDGs Report; Enhanced advocacy and communication on SDGs.

1. UNDP supported MOJCA with the alignment of 1 of the 4 family related laws; the Marriages Act. The review involved stakeholders engagement including the traditional authorities. The Act now awaits to be submitted to parliament for endorsement. Due to limited resources, the progress on the alignment of the identified laws has been slow. The review and alignment of the Estates Act has also been started with an internal drafting process. The review of the 2010 National Gender Policy is underway for completion in the second quarter of 2019. The Inception Report for the project has been produced. 2. The International and Regional Treaty Reporting was enabled for the CEDAW Third Report, Maputo declaration and SADC Protocol drafts. UNDP together with UNICEF supported the Deputy Prime Ministers office with the development and finalisation of the The National Disability and Implementation Plan which has been launched. This has led to the fast-tracking on the treaty reporting on Disability. Through Joint work with OHCHR institutional design and training of human capacity for 30 Officers from across Government Ministries international treaty body reporting focusing in particular on the Disability Report has been facilitated. Engagement of national Stakeholders on UPR and ICCPR recommendations has been facilitated. The outcome of this facilitation is the monitoring plan for implementation of the recommendations. 3. Not achieved. 4. Workshop was facilitated for heads f departments of 7 key service Ministries (Agriculture Health, education, Home Affairs, Natural Resources and Public Works) involved in Public Service delivery to disseminate the results of the Public service perception study and develop an action plan on how to roll out recommendations and to develop public Service score cards. 5. Due to resource constraints this was not achieved. 6. The Drafting of the Anti Corruption Policy was initiated, however due to Resources Constraints could not be finalised. 7. Support was extended to the gender Unit and family unit for the media campaign for the vote for women campaign in collaboration with UNFPA. 8. Dissemination of the Sexual Harassment Assessment Report facilitated involving stakeholders from private sector. The outcome from this dissemination study is the development of an action plan.
